dialogues.ANDY:
[1]Hallo.  I am Andy.  Welcoom to my movie. I hoped the story of my life would be nice...but it turned out terrible!  It is all LIES!  Tings are mixed up... real people I knew play different people.  WHAT A MESS! So I broke into Universal and cut out the junk.  Now it's much shorter.  In fact, this is the end of the movie.  So tanks for comink! Bye-bye! 
[2]Okay!  Just my friends are left.  I wanted to get rid of those other people... they would have laughed in the wrong places. I was only kidding about the movie... it's actually PRETTY GOOD! It shows everything... from me as a little boy until my death -- Oops!!  I wasn't supposed to talk about that!  Oh.  Eh, uh, we better just begin.  It starts back in Great Neck, Long Island... 
[3]Oh, yes.  I remember it well...

Tonight I had to come from, eh, and the freeway, it was so much traffic.  It took me an hour and a half to get here! But -- talking about the terrible things: My wife.  Take my wife, please take her. No really, I am only foolink.  I love my wife very much.  But she don't know how to cook.  You know, one time, she make a steak and mashed potato.  Ehh, and the night before, she make spaghetti and meatballs.  Her cooking is so bad... is terrible. Right now, I would like to do for you some imitations.  So first, I would like to imitate Archie Bunker. "You stupid, everybody ees stupid! Ehh, get, get out of my chair Meathead... go in the, eh, Dingbat get into the kitchen, making the food!  Ehh, everybody ees stupid!  I don't like nobody, ees so stupid!" Tank you veddy much. Now I would like to imitate Jimmy Carter, the President of the United States. "Hello, I am Jimmy Carter, the President of the United States." And now... I would like to imitate the Elvis Presley.

[78]So do you wanna wrestle?

[98]Chapter One. "In my younger and more vulnerable years, my father gave me some advice that I've been turning over in my mind ever since.  'Whenever you feel like criticizing anyone,' he told me, 'just remember that all the people in this world haven't had the advantages you've had.'" "He didn't say any more, but we've always been unusually communicative in a reserved way, and I understood that he meant a great deal more than that..." 
[99]Tank you veddy much!!!! 
[100]"When I came back from the East last autumn, I felt that I wanted the world to be in uniform and at a sort of moral attention forever; I wanted no more riotous excursions with privileged glimpses into the human heart..." Please, let's keep it down.  We have a long way to go. "Only Gatsby, the man who gives his name to this book, was exempt from my reaction - Gatsby, who represented everything for which I have an unaffected scorn..." 
[101]Chapter Two. 
[102]"Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy's running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby's party.  Perhaps his presence gave the evening its peculiar quality of oppressiveness..." 
[103]Look!  I don't have to tolerate this impoliteness!  Forget it -- I'm gonna stop the show.  GOODBYE! No, no, I'm only fooling. I'll tell you what.  Would you rather have me continue reading or would you like to hear the phonograph record? 
[104]"His presence gave the evening its peculiar quality of oppressiveness - it stands out in my memory from Gatsby's other parties that summer..." 
[105]"Tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms farther... And one fine morning - So we beat on, boats against the current borne back ceaselessly into the past." The End. 
[106]Let's get some breakfast.

So NOW, Tony denying being me is the truth!  Tony's not me!  But maybe he is!  The audience will never know... They'll think they're laughin' at me -- but actually I'll be laughin' at them, because they're wrong and I'm right!

dialogues.GEORGE:
[1]Pst.  What's the story with this guy? 
[2]He does a hell of an Elvis. 
[3]Hey, I really enjoyed your set. 
[4]So I understand you're from Lithuania? 
[5]Caspiar?  I haven't heard of that. 
[6]Oh.  Hm.  I'm uh, sorry. Well, look, I'm probably out of my mind -- but I think you're very interesting.  If you ever need representation... we should talk. 
[7]Caspiar, huh?! 
[8]People love... comedians. 
[9]You show a lot of promise... but... my concern is I don't know where to book you.  You're not a stand-up... your act doesn't exactly translate to films... help me... where do you see yourself? 
[10]Yeah, ha-ha.  That's funny. 
[11]You're insane. But -- you might also be brilliant. Alright, Andy... let's do it. 
[12]Sammy, opening for David Brenner is a fine gig.  You'll be on the road... get some exposure... 
[13]Who? 
[14]Oh. Sammy, think about it.  I gotta go. Hello?  George Shapiro here. 
[15]Er, yes.  Speaking. 
[16]Can I help you with something? 
[17]Who is this? 
[18]Look... I don't know what your problem is...

If he'd picked leukemia, it'd be totally believable, and we'd all be going, "Poor Andy, he's really sick."  So he chose lung cancer, because he WANTS us to be scratching our heads, saying, "Is this real?"

TONY CLIFTON! Ladies and Gentlemen, out of respect for Mr. Clifton's vocal demands, could everyone please extinguish your cigarettes and cigars.

[5]And Kaufman's left the ring again! He doesn't seem interested in actually making contact with his opponent. 
[6]It's a side suplex!! 
[7]Lawler has committed a PILEDRIVER, which is an AUTOMATIC DISQUALIFICATION!  Match goes to Kaufman by disqualification, after two minutes, twelve seconds! 
[8]Ladies and Gentlemen!  Please put your hands together for... Tony Clifton!
dialogues.MIMI:
[1]... so after I finish junior college, I'll go to work for my dad's accounting firm.  Unless, I decide to live with my friend Valerie, but she wants to move to Anaheim, and I don't want to do that. 
[2]Excuse me -- ? 
[3]What are you talking about?!  We just met an hour ago. 
[4]I don't wanna talk about it! 
[5]The sunset is really beautiful. 
[6]I mean -- uh -- the colors in the sky are so vibrant.  I love this time of day. 
[7]I think I wanna go home.
dialogues.BOOKER:
[1]Mr. Shapiro, this is Gene Knight, up at Harrah's Tahoe.  We'd like to book Andy Kaufman for our showroom. 
[2]Oh. What about Tony Clifton? 
[3]Eh, sure.  We're trying to expand our audience base -- and I know the college kids really love Andy Kaufman. 
[4]Yeah, yeah, yeah.  I know! Wink wink!  Nudge nudge! 
[5]I'll take my chances!! 
[6]Why's that?  You said over and over and over, Tony Clifton is not Andy Kaufman -- 
[7]Sure it is.  Tony called me himself. He yelled at me, insisting that his dressing room be bigger than Andy's. They're both going on tonight, believe me!
dialogues.MICHAEL:
[1]He's inside. 
[2]Afterwards, I'll take you backstage. You can meet my brother. 
[3]Andy...! 
[4]Mom, it's Cedars-Sinai!  It's a showbiz hospital!  Andy's studio friends probably run this place! 
[5]Did you notice his costume had the wrong shoes? 
[6]We all know he's talked about faking his own death...
dialogues.MANAGER:
[1]The comedy stylings of Andy Kaufman, Ladies and Gentlemen! 
[2]Eh, I dunno... Andy.  I'm... thinkin' of letting you go... 
[3]Look -- I don't wanna seem insulting.  But... your act is like amateur hour: Singalongs... puppets... playing records... 
[4]Sure!  Comedy!  Make jokes about the traffic.  Do impressions.  Maybe a little blue material... 
[5]Well, everyone else gets this place cookin'!  Pal, it's hard for me to move the booze when you're singin' "Pop Goes The Weasel." 
[6]I'm sorry.  You're finished here.
dialogues.LORNE MICHAELS:
[1]What's happening to him? 
[2]Oh my God, he's doing nothing.  It's dead air...! 
[3]George -- I don't know if Andy works for our show anymore.  That wrestling stuff... is such a turnoff. 
[4]That's smart. 
[5]Okay.  It'd be good to have the old Andy back. 
[6]Jesus Christ.
dialogues.MELANIE:
[1]"If you say so." 
[2]You okay, honey?  Something wrong, Carl? 
[3]You feel stupid?  What about us?! 
[4]You JERK! 
[5]Oh my God --! 
[6]He's a fuckin' psycho!
